9CAC55608F56403E89E342097D7F01F2.description: Vision chemistry involves the light activated interconversion of cis- and trans- isomers of retinal.

C3B8EEA658F3434ABDCFC9AF91433899.description: Ring forms of sugars have isomers, known as α and β, depending on whether the position of the hydroxyl group at carbon 1 (glucose) or carbon 2 (fructose) lies below the plane of the ring (α) or above the plane of the ring (β).

B05C06F9974147298D4E741DCFFDF0F2.description: D and L stereoisomers of sugars refer to the configuration of the chiral carbon atom furthest from the aldehyde or ketone group, and D forms occur most frequently in nature.

738FF2BFD54444CFA63BED65DFE4AD0F.description: Naturally occurring unsaturated fat is mostly in the cis form, but food processing can convert it into the trans form.

A9BF336939574CA581C0D682FCA06101.description: With one exception, amino acids are chiral, and only the L-configuration is found in proteins.

D864499FA6CD41EF8A30EBC62E1E8994.description: Carotenoids are lipid-soluble pigments, and are involved in harvesting light in photosynthesis. They are susceptible to oxidation, catalysed by light.

11170D662E2C4A5D831BF3EAE8F6FCD1.description: Anthocyanins are aromatic, water-soluble pigments widely distributed in plants. Their specific colour depends on metal ions and pH.

4D716DF64D074C8187DE459FEA41C1AD.description: Cytochromes contain heme groups in which the iron ion interconverts between iron(II) and iron(III) during redox reactions.

3529A5AD67E14D3D8E999C47CB6D85C9.description: Hemoglobin and myoglobin contain heme groups with the porphyrin group bound to an iron(II) ion.

C4D9728880A5434AAA8544D9564A96D3.description: Porphyrin compounds, such as hemoglobin, myoglobin, chlorophyll and many cytochromes are chelates of metals with large nitrogen-containing macrocyclic ligands.

AAD0FE4C4F0E42DEAC8D3BDE8993CBAC.description: The colour of pigments is due to highly conjugated systems with delocalized electrons, which have intense absorption bands in the visible region.

950E9A8CA0CE4314BC93FBACB96C20F7.description: Biological pigments are coloured compounds produced by metabolism.

6D9D9C845D90429F9FE5A8B81B85CF12.description: Genetically modified organisms have genetic material that has been altered by genetic engineering techniques, involving transferring DNA between species.

82941064EA6246AA95F1CD165AE75502.description: The sequence of bases in DNA determines the primary structure of proteins synthesized by the cell using a triplet code, known as the genetic code, which is universal.

CFA0DD9917DC47ED81B3E8972DA8201D.description: RNA is usually a single polynucleotide chain that contains uracil in place of thymine, and a sugar ribose in place of deoxyribose.

02EC1B74785F495FB6D6CFD7050EA860.description: DNA is a double helix of two polynucleotide strands held together by hydrogen bonds.

50FC65DE11334BF5AD9728E8AC972CF9.description: Nucleotides are the condensation products of a pentose sugar, phosphoric acid and a nitrogenous base—adenine (A), guanine (G), cytosine (C), thymine (T) or uracil (U).

8015A2C50F944F2394498EE1C07B3C8B.description: Protein assays commonly use UV-vis spectroscopy and a calibration curve based on known standards.

B7E339BD9F8145A18A01A34B8894FF89.description: Amino acids and proteins can act as buffers in solution.

70AE49C34FC84FE78A00C6AA96061495.description: Inhibitors play an important role in regulating the activities of enzymes.

C14CC0255FD14D0FA0879DAE560C38BF.description: Green chemistry, also called sustainable chemistry, is an approach to chemical research and engineering that seeks to minimize the production and release to the environment of hazardous substances.

D95D9E2FD7584CF69F04B1DB4F8B87FA.description: Biomagnification is the increase in concentration of a substance in a food chain.

DD6C7D921EAD483FAC60628D4A31994E.description: Enzymes in biological detergents can improve energy efficiency by enabling effective cleaning at lower temperatures.

8900089C580E444BA6DD10645206B5F6.description: Enzymes have been developed to help in the breakdown of oil spills and other industrial wastes.

CFD3A49261444A309BC74E28B8745B02.description: Host–guest chemistry involves the creation of synthetic host molecules that mimic some of the actions performed by enzymes in cells, by selectively binding to specific guest species, such as toxic materials in the environment.

C96E1B13B7F447B09E5E27F58312271C.description: Biodegradable/compostable plastics can be consumed or broken down by bacteria or other living organisms.

F0A6F14BB386401B95AAD5CA678EFCD8.description: Xenobiotics refer to chemicals that are found in an organism that are not normally present there.

2E8020020D5041C992E6140B69D1B98C.description:
Vitamin deficiencies in the diet cause particular diseases and affect millions of
people worldwide.

DE3114592DA545B0AAA7818D2B9D85E5.description: Most vitamins are sensitive to heat.

9EC24DAEFAC045A6A606D3CC74103265.description: The solubility (water or fat) of a vitamin can be predicted from its structure.

1FDC833A7EFB4879A0BF9C4C9A5E2723.description:
Vitamins are organic micronutrients which (mostly) cannot be synthesized by
the body but must be obtained from suitable food sources.

668CB585293B46EEB3C8C6F3E6D79E07.description: Carbohydrates are used as energy sources and energy reserves.

781FE7FDFD5944BA8CFCF2840E22C109.description:
Glycosidic bonds form between monosaccharides forming disaccharides and
polysaccharides.

CA93BD1AA5DE461993E715BA18B819A3.description:
Straight chain forms of sugars cyclize in solution to form ring structures
containing an ether linkage.

366EC00E051C4B8FBEB4BD55D3BCAD97.description:
Monosaccharides contain either an aldehyde group (aldose) or a ketone group
(ketose) and several –OH groups.

1F660508535F48778F7CCFFB4D8C0A90.description: Haworth projections represent the cyclic structures of monosaccharides.

F6D7DEDA258145AE99D7E393C7B39050.description: Carbohydrates have the general formula Cx(H2O)y.

4E65951F69014CD2A4A4EEE72F64D7EE.description:
Lipids act as structural components of cell membranes, in energy storage,
thermal and electrical insulation, as transporters of lipid soluble vitamins and as
hormones.

22C0406A24F74F74892B0DC9538878E5.description:
Steroids have a characteristic fused ring structure, known as a steroidal
backbone

DD9D311D43DA4E0EB6D7855314E2D804.description:
Hydrolysis of triglycerides and phospholipids can occur using enzymes or in
alkaline or acidic conditions.

B1649C8F7E53433994FDB27C53CF71BF.description:
Triglycerides are produced by condensation of glycerol with three fatty acids
and contain ester links. Fatty acids can be saturated, monounsaturated or
polyunsaturated.

D9DC58494C064C3486A0F7F2507C15CD.description:
Fats are more reduced than carbohydrates and so yield more energy when
oxidized.

48EB5AC5BC174C12BD5733EB6E413880.description:
Chromatography separation is based on different physical and chemical
principles.

8E4CDDC4E9C1411497AE307D19B2BB6B.description:
As enzyme activity depends on the conformation, it is sensitive to changes in
temperature and pH and the presence of heavy metal ions.

11718D148E014C1CB5F7B4D1AF75E61A.description:
A protein’s three-dimensional shape determines its role in structural
components or in metabolic processes.

4AE3CDC0A6D74C2BADD5BC054405F712.description:
A protein’s three-dimensional shape determines its role in structural
components or in metabolic processes.

2C522B7268E94F63B92AFF8094AF68DE.description:
Protein structures are diverse and are described at the primary, secondary,
tertiary and quaternary levels.

0B5435D2BD1546E895D99D74ADEF5AC9.description: Amino acids are amphoteric and can exist as zwitterions, cations and anions.

498328A294C24893961C4D4E2F9A458F.description:
Proteins are polymers of 2-amino acids, joined by amide links (also known as
peptide bonds).

00FE4AE776F644DAA49670505431074A.description: Respiration is a complex set of metabolic processes providing energy for cells.

4749886C12B14B5C8C49D886D4068F59.description: Photosynthesis is the synthesis of energy-rich molecules from carbon dioxide and water using light energy.

01FCD7689D88422EAF65D1113CB7A38C.description: Biopolymers form by condensation reactions and are broken down by hydrolysis reactions.

933AAC1FF772496B9CE286D47CF42875.description: Reactions of breakdown are called catabolism and reactions of synthesis are called anabolism.

23F0A50E23A44927B322056702CDAEEC.description: Metabolic reactions take place in highly controlled aqueous environments.

48847DE665DD419D92B4C71CD72A2CE9.description: The diverse functions of biological molecules depend on their structures and shapes.

93EBCA42C5624BECA416C74222B76569.description: The structural technique of single crystal X-ray crystallography can be used to identify the bond lengths and bond angles of crystalline compounds.

3B3F4D67731948C6B047EFE7BC350D02.description: In a high resolution 1H NMR spectrum, single peaks present in low resolution can split into further clusters of peaks.

4D72B2D7327C41E6A238BE9D7F27E2EA.description: Structural identification of compounds involves several different analytical techniques including IR, 1H NMR and MS.

0F530397416848BAAA1BC4CD216FC433.description: A racemic mixture (or racemate) is a mixture of two enantiomers in equal amounts and is optically inactive.

9544D74ED5774B0FA449A567580E80CB.description: An optically active compound can rotate the plane of polarized light as it passes through a solution of the compound. Optical isomers are enantiomers. Enantiomers are non-superimposeable mirror images of each other. Diastereomers are not mirror images of each other.

6211A836B89E4ED2B54982F16D9B384B.description: A chiral carbon is a carbon joined to four different atoms or groups.

E529A3718FF34FB491A996EBB2EBF411.description: Cis-trans isomers can occur in alkenes or cycloalkanes (or heteroanalogues) and differ in the positions of atoms (or groups) relative to a reference plane. According to IUPAC, E/Z isomers refer to alkenes of the form R1R2C=CR3R4 (R1 ≠ R2, R3 ≠ R4) where neither R1 nor R2 need be different from R3 or R4.

B3CC01266ABB4489A8304FAFA4E81117.description:
Stereoisomers are subdivided into two classes—conformational isomers, which
interconvert by rotation about a σ bond and configurational isomers that
interconvert only by breaking and reforming a bond. Configurational isomers are further subdivided into cis-trans and E/Z isomers
and optical isomers.

213DF01D9A92465CAD1E3844522A9346.description: The synthesis of an organic compound stems from a readily available starting material via a series of discrete steps. Functional group interconversions are the basis of such synthetic routes.

FA1861EB72834501AE3AE2132D51FE2E.description: Reduction Reactions: Carboxylic acids can be reduced to primary alcohols (via the aldehyde). Ketones can be reduced to secondary alcohols. Typical reducing agents are lithium aluminium hydride (used to reduce carboxylic acids) and sodium borohydride.

20526076E7014BA7B174F6EA6E888D61.description: Electrophilic Substitution Reactions: Benzene is the simplest aromatic hydrocarbon compound (or arene) and has a delocalized structure of π bonds around its ring. Each carbon to carbon bond has a bond order of 1.5. Benzene is susceptible to attack by electrophiles.

26D2A6ABDB164DB08FB9E875E181D89A.description: Electrophilic Addition Reactions:  Markovnikov’s rule can be applied to predict the major product in electrophilic addition reactions of unsymmetrical alkenes with hydrogen halides and interhalogens. The formation of the major product can be explained in terms of the relative stability of possible carbocations in the reaction mechanism.

DEB0CFDA5AFE4B8BAA3573BD52E25D88.description:
Electrophilic Addition Reactions:  An electrophile is an electron-deficient species that can accept electron pairs
from a nucleophile. Electrophiles are Lewis acids.

F380C1475D854474A1B203ED59D734D1.description:
Nucleophilic Substitutions Reactions: SN2 reactions are best conducted using aprotic, non-polar solvents and SN1
reactions are best conducted using protic, polar solvents.

886108F3A5C148A0996F92650EDD0E31.description:
Nucleophilic Substitutions Reactions: The rate determining step (slow step) in an SN1 reaction depends only on
the concentration of the halogenoalkane, rate = k[halogenoalkane]. For SN2,
rate = k[halogenoalkane][nucleophile]. SN2 is stereospecific with an inversion
of configuration at the carbon.

8DE59B1AD92E494F96686BB92D711E28.description:
Nucleophilic Substitutions Reactions: For tertiary halogenoalkanes the predominant mechanism is SN1 and for
primary halogenoalkanes it is SN2. Both mechanisms occur for secondary
halogenoalkanes.

070803ABBD574118AA069588897C1517.description:
Nucleophilic Substitutions Reactions: SN1 represents a nucleophilic unimolecular substitution reaction and SN2
represents a nucleophilic bimolecular substitution reaction. SN1 involves a
carbocation intermediate. SN2 involves a concerted reaction with a transition
state.

49315723AC264EB785F94A8DB12E3FF5.description: Electroplating involves the electrolytic coating of an object with a metallic thin layer.

B1398271608A4379B39E3962680EAB7E.description:
Current, duration of electrolysis and charge on the ion affect the amount of
product formed at the electrodes during electrolysis.

3B1860032D7D4F3698E51C1C153352A4.description:
G= -nFE. When Eº is positive, Gº is negative indicative of a spontaneous
process. When Eº is negative, Gº is positive indicative of a non-spontaneous
process. When Eº is 0, then Gº is 0.

0A96AE90C3DF41289A0C0D0B29728EA2.description:
When aqueous solutions are electrolysed, water can be oxidized to oxygen at
the anode and reduced to hydrogen at the cathode.

5BFEF2851B6A43E4BB3053C89ECB9980.description:
The standard hydrogen electrode (SHE) consists of an inert platinum electrode
in contact with 1 mol dm-3 hydrogen ion and hydrogen gas at 100 kPa and 298
K. The standard electrode potential (Eº) is the potential (voltage) of the
reduction half-equation under standard conditions measured relative to the
SHE. Solute concentration is 1 mol dm-3 or 100 kPa for gases. Eº of the SHE is
0 V.

CCF39E1C6A8E411AAF5BCF20CDE5B84B.description:
A voltaic cell generates an electromotive force (EMF) resulting in the movement
of electrons from the anode (negative electrode) to the cathode (positive
electrode) via the external circuit. The EMF is termed the cell potential (Eº).

3C4608E2BBAB41309C7DE122B155EC35.description: The composition and action of a buffer solution.

947F803E760B4150852497B9782146BD.description:
The buffer region on the pH curve represents the region where small additions
of acid or base result in little or no change in pH.

5C1B52586B5F4DA18C5E87953BD43CFB.description:
The relationship between the pH range of an acid–base indicator, which is a
weak acid, and its pKa value.

9E08DEC0710C48D4B363482F87BA9DF3.description:
An acid–base indicator is a weak acid or a weak base where the components of
the conjugate acid–base pair have different colours.

AA443C8A2FE246479427C0F50709CC26.description:
The characteristics of the pH curves produced by the different combinations of
strong and weak acids and bases.

7A850170BC0C40E191683E8054A8F646.description: The relationship between Ka and pKa is (pKa = -log Ka), and between Kb and pKb is (pKb = -log Kb).

A36537ABC0D6449186DF3B145416211C.description: For a conjugate acid base pair, Ka × Kb = Kw.

1667E1FC93384052842EF62BE002623D.description: The expression for the dissociation constant of a weak acid (Ka) and a weak base (Kb).

63404FF6210F426B95623614D41FD22C.description: A nucleophile is a Lewis base and an electrophile is a Lewis acid.

53D0DB9591C84448A303227089FC0990.description: When a Lewis base reacts with a Lewis acid a coordinate bond is formed.

E4F73EB59AB24116A881C82FDD4BEB9D.description: A Lewis acid is a lone pair acceptor and a Lewis base is a lone pair donor

BBAAE089EB9041A98AFBD4FB170D10DE.description:
The Gibbs free energy change of a reaction and the equilibrium constant can
both be used to measure the position of an equilibrium reaction and are related
by the equation, ∆𝐺 = −𝑅 ln𝐾 .

EE3E55D691E84F948E855026944B3DA8.description:
The position of equilibrium corresponds to a maximum value of entropy and a
minimum in the value of the Gibbs free energy.

E14FE585B02C4497B83AEDF49469153B.description:
Le Châtelier’s principle for changes in concentration can be explained by the
equilibrium law.

92CFA0D1EE5A4185BC40EF5CE87183F9.description: The frequency factor (or pre-exponential factor) (A) takes into account the frequency of collisions with proper orientations.

F5F30401B1024C7CA243E0299ED6D930.description: A graph of 1/T against ln k is a linear plot with gradient – Ea / R and intercept, lnA.

3BF84926ADD64C5880856B92BD4DCE1C.description: The Arrhenius equation uses the temperature dependence of the rate constant to determine the activation energy.

5A31477E37444207961168186C16F3AD.description: Catalysts alter a reaction mechanism, introducing a step with lower activation energy.

5FF4490EAE024277B5397D2F24F7F689.description: The value of the rate constant (k) is affected by temperature and its units are determined from the overall order of the reaction.

C67D51EB5FDD43F38D393C3F01E34753.description: Rate equations can only be determined experimentally.

58BD5413AE47431E8E80A9E7E2E11D9B.description: The order of a reaction can be either integer or fractional in nature. The order of a reaction can describe, with respect to a reactant, the number of particles taking part in the rate-determining step.

B2F0FB5E5C8E47158957FB355EA6C4F5.description: The molecularity of an elementary step is the number of reactant particles taking part in that step.

F9E5BB61E67A4A41A2E4FFE7A17EFB6B.description: Reactions may occur by more than one step and the slowest step determines the rate of reaction (rate determining step/RDS).

78EE769C693743B89928DBCA628EB340.description: Entropy of gas>liquid>solid under same conditions.

A59E1B347F7E4C7792FB5CA10839C2E4.description:
Gibbs free energy (G) relates the energy that can be obtained from a chemical
reaction to the change in enthalpy (ΔH), change in entropy (ΔS), and absolute
temperature (T).

D6E0F04C21F04013B6C185ED86C86D48.description:
Entropy (S) refers to the distribution of available energy among the particles.
The more ways the energy can be distributed the higher the entropy.

43BFAED213CE41A3A5A6E85C6FB8D5B0.description: Enthalpy of solution, hydration enthalpy and lattice enthalpy are related in an energy cycle.

20C4F1746B89481B963A8949703812E7.description: Representative equations (eg M+(g)--> M+(aq)) can be used for enthalpy/energy of hydration, ionization, atomization, electron affinity, lattice, covalent bond and solution.

390268BC2A0A4B75A35029A3553DD73F.description:
A hybrid orbital results from the mixing of different types of atomic orbitals on
the same atom.

25E40EB1AAF9402FA88A00DC863DA000.description:
Resonance involves using two or more Lewis (electron dot) structures to
represent a particular molecule or ion. A resonance structure is one of two or
more alternative Lewis (electron dot) structures for a molecule or ion that
cannot be described fully with one Lewis (electron dot) structure alone.

CD9E2076692E4580A387FA862DE43490.description:
Delocalization involves electrons that are shared by/between all atoms in a
molecule or ion as opposed to being localized between a pair of atoms.

DD5D75BC38B44595A80BC6215B36F9D9.description:
Exceptions to the octet rule include some species having incomplete octets
and expanded octets.

D522AA8E071B4C3B820FCB583A7EAE81.description:
Formal charge (FC) can be used to decide which Lewis (electron dot) structure
is preferred from several. The FC is the charge an atom would have if all atoms
in the molecule had the same electronegativity. FC = (Number of valence
electrons)-½(Number of bonding electrons)-(Number of non-bonding
electrons). The Lewis (electron dot) structure with the atoms having FC values
closest to zero is preferred.

8213F0711ABD4F16B7400FD7C7622EEA.description:
Covalent bonds result from the overlap of atomic orbitals. A sigma bond (σ) is
formed by the direct head-on/end-to-end overlap of atomic orbitals, resulting in
electron density concentrated between the nuclei of the bonding atoms. A pi
bond (π) is formed by the sideways overlap of atomic orbitals, resulting in
electron density above and below the plane of the nuclei of the bonding atoms.

944228140B7540F3A62868B14C23450B.description: Further aspects of covalent bonding and structure

6D0C0CE7D77E4005A8D0BAB58C8B00FA.description: The colour absorbed is complementary to the colour observed.

DD84F3DCC0EE46219B143CE807EDF7FA.description:
Complexes of d-block elements are coloured, as light is absorbed when an
electron is excited between the d-orbitals.

C110B0B5FAB84C608FC31600EEB3CE00.description:
The d sub-level splits into two sets of orbitals of different energy in a complex
ion.

82FCA3CE69544DA58F25C8AF5EE1D7D2.description: Transition elements show an oxidation state of +2 when the s-electrons are removed.

7AA7F50A165342C4AF1A6499A9CFB913.description: Zn is not considered to be a transition element as it does not form ions with incomplete d-orbitals.

9997EC2735A94F7C8A34D9D7A8FE4E3A.description: Transition elements have variable oxidation states, form complex ions with ligands, have coloured compounds, and display catalytic and magnetic properties.

13A02ADF99114AF3ABF50376A5EF667A.description:
Successive ionization energy data for an element give information that shows
relations to electron configurations.

66D80E237CAF48ACA5508E8B55E2D45F.description:
Trends in first ionization energy across periods account for the existence of
main energy levels and sub-levels in atoms.

44D9DF268B18498493691D69013C5A53.description:
In an emission spectrum, the limit of convergence at higher frequency
corresponds to the first ionization energy.

7EADCE1EE09343DFAD5F3E45589D39B5.description:
Mass spectrometry (MS), proton nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H
NMR) and infrared spectroscopy (IR) are techniques that can be used to help
identify compounds and to determine their structure.

BAC57812A0FB489CAF974455598C29BC.description:
The degree of unsaturation or index of hydrogen deficiency (IHD) can be used
to determine from a molecular formula the number of rings or multiple bonds in
a molecule.

17850C67754A43A1BBEB57CC1015CFC7.description: Drawn graphs have labelled and scaled axes, and are used in quantitative measurements.

2FAE5A6144464B11A9BC7ABF2DB51162.description: Sketched graphs have labelled but unscaled axes, and are used to show qualitative trends, such as variables that are proportional or inversely proportional.

4814940A28DD4288867ED3FC516F4AB5.description: Graphical techniques are an effective means of communicating the effect of an independent variable on a dependent variable, and can lead to determination of physical quantities.

229E51CC64A54178892363B271CA4131.description: Repeat trials and measurements will reduce random errors but not systematic errors.

E3FADED0BDC2441D9F89FBEE32416789.description: Experimental design and procedure usually lead to systematic errors in measurement, which cause a deviation in a particular direction.

D0FEA091109A45F6AFA804E2541C8191.description: Propagation of random errors in data processing shows the impact of the uncertainties on the final result.

95A6B8807D474FC7856D3ADC14FDE820.description: Quantitative data are obtained from measurements, and are always associated with random errors/uncertainties, determined by the apparatus, and by human limitations such as reaction times.

0AC438CD923F469DBA118A8A259A32BA.description: Qualitative data includes all non-numerical information obtained from observations not from measurement.

19F755BFB5AD45EB9552875A2CA72621.description: Uncertainties and errors in measurement and results

7D25E677484F4D05AC8DA9060304F83D.description:
Benzene does not readily undergo addition reactions but does undergo
electrophilic substitution reactions.

630C37D26E214B8AAD3EF721A4C054CE.description:
Addition polymers consist of a wide range of monomers and form the basis of
the plastics industry.

31EFB57E0AC64F9796EB4A44E40603CC.description:
Halogenoalkanes are more reactive than alkanes. They can undergo
(nucleophilic) substitution reactions. A nucleophile is an electron-rich species
containing a lone pair that it donates to an electron-deficient carbon.

9C5E5329C6354612BB9F3C6B3FF979A1.description:
Alcohols undergo nucleophilic substitution reactions with acids (also called
esterification or condensation) and some undergo oxidation reactions.

FA1EA98E3B024109A72AE08C21D0F9EE.description:
Alkenes are more reactive than alkanes and undergo addition reactions.
Bromine water can be used to distinguish between alkenes and alkanes.

1FAD738C74924175838E9847624C3A68.description: Alkanes have low reactivity and undergo free-radical substitution reactions.

5A6D2C45D2DE4F6D81F8455A8601AD9C.description: Benzene is an aromatic, unsaturated hydrocarbon.

DA95BDF3CCD044E481AA75C270A7D8F0.description:
Saturated compounds contain single bonds only and unsaturated compounds
contain double or triple bonds.

472F16447331467094D0D884799F6A24.description: Functional groups are the reactive parts of molecules.

33CEBBADEFD648B7BB15C04B00096C97.description:
Structural isomers are compounds with the same molecular formula but
different arrangements of atoms.

A744D6928A644E329176272ED482C45F.description: Structural formulas can be represented in full and condensed format.

6E371A00D3E2403D9E1A62FE94030079.description:
A homologous series is a series of compounds of the same family, with the
same general formula, which differ from each other by a common structural
unit.

B720D4651B3A46BDB8682DC028EB551C.description:
Electrolytic Cells: Oxidation occurs at the anode (positive electrode) and reduction occurs at the
cathode (negative electrode) in an electrolytic cell.

FC3B4F070E2E4F839656A5D168D370D8.description:
Electrolytic Cells: Electrolytic cells convert electrical energy to chemical energy, by bringing about
non-spontaneous processes.

F2D8133374CB4EEB97120F9428BA4F74.description:
Voltaic Cells: Oxidation occurs at the anode (negative electrode) and reduction occurs at the
cathode (positive electrode) in a voltaic cell.

C73B006E3CE7497D8309AB443CB842C2.description:
Voltaic Cells: Voltaic cells convert energy from spontaneous, exothermic chemical processes
to electrical energy.

AEF9CAD648384B70BD88AA43D229B445.description:
The Winkler Method can be used to measure biochemical oxygen demand
(BOD), used as a measure of the degree of pollution in a water sample.

0CC3206F349E45C1B314421A84BD3658.description:
The activity series ranks metals according to the ease with which they undergo
oxidation.

9E414B1A4B3540FAB09B4B48D7CBC576.description:
Variable oxidation numbers exist for transition metals and for most main-group
non-metals.

8EC5562BF0CC4E139AF8295D314CCCEC.description: An oxidizing agent is reduced and a reducing agent is oxidized.

E319B516FD7743E0B3978DBFC5B94C45.description:
Oxidation and reduction can be considered in terms of oxygen gain/hydrogen
loss, electron transfer or change in oxidation number.

7825BA7D32C3426CA6A11ECA137630CE.description: Sources of the oxides of sulfur and nitrogen and the effects of acid deposition should be covered.

C203374A6C7841EB8020CC7871EFDF5E.description: Acid deposition is formed when nitrogen or sulfur oxides dissolve in water to form HNO3, HNO2, H2SO4 and H2SO3.

05C7A65330554DD5B6AA74DDD691B25E.description: Rain is naturally acidic because of dissolved CO2 and has a pH of 5.6. Acid deposition has a pH below 5.6.

2F3AF8AD95084071B6DA8DE7780988FB.description: A strong base is a good proton acceptor and has a weak conjugate acid.

5FFE4A5542894289B1D6DF9DBAD14C81.description: A strong acid is a good proton donor and has a weak conjugate base.

754BC72E9B21458FA0B76CBE2090DC62.description:
Strong acids and bases of equal concentrations have higher conductivities than
weak acids and bases.

A3C37A01DAF54317ABEA8E0A39B56825.description: Strong and weak acids and bases differ in the extent of ionization.

DFB1FFED27824E18AEABA1DC87F40C69.description: Strong and weak acids and bases

D83CB867BCF64C05AC385206DCDCC571.description: The ionic product constant, 𝐾𝑤 = [H+][OH−] = 10−14 at 298 K.

1B2C95173B7048A582FEBD4C9EB14BC8.description: pH values distinguish between acidic, neutral and alkaline solutions.

1644ED0F43E642B88D64F4BDAAD5435B.description: A change of one pH unit represents a 10-fold change in the hydrogen ion concentration [𝐻+].

01B52A9AB6584A5A808E06F05E47048F.description: Salt and water are produced in exothermic neutralization reactions.

2ADF1E184FE841ED8F8FBC8A222EA05C.description:
Most acids have observable characteristic chemical reactions with reactive
metals, metal oxides, metal hydroxides, hydrogen carbonates and carbonates.

509D8E3E416745AC82AACE9FEFA9C0A9.description: A pair of species differing by a single proton is called a conjugate acid-base pair.

204262E386474757922C3E0D65BF5C9D.description: Amphiprotic species can act as both Brønsted–Lowry acids and bases.

5EABF3F80F17422AB6BC86BD60A3A047.description: A Brønsted–Lowry acid is a proton/H+ donor and a Brønsted–Lowry base is a proton/H+ acceptor.

D70A71C1726041FC8213827C48266452.description:
A catalyst has no effect on the position of equilibrium or the equilibrium
constant.

9B237905F79745C4B5614D6B1149719F.description:
The reaction quotient (Q) measures the relative amount of products and
reactants present during a reaction at a particular point in time. Q is the
equilibrium expression with non-equilibrium concentrations. The position of the
equilibrium changes with changes in concentration, pressure, and temperature.

B2691ACC5FF74E7591CF3A5CE8D557BB.description:
The magnitude of the equilibrium constant indicates the extent of a reaction at
equilibrium and is temperature dependent.

F9B74A136BA4488BBBB98ACF7A4F6868.description:
The equilibrium law describes how the equilibrium constant (Kc) can be
determined for a particular chemical reaction.

E76EE0DABAC44369A3FB3FA8BA05F32D.description:
A state of equilibrium is reached in a closed system when the rates of the
forward and reverse reactions are equal.

E2D9CE6548C44101A13CF664C7D918E2.description:
By decreasing Ea, a catalyst increases the rate of a chemical reaction, without
itself being permanently chemically changed.

758BF2532B044B38B9E3FD3CB7A62449.description:
Activation energy (Ea) is the minimum energy that colliding molecules need in
order to have successful collisions leading to a reaction.

7F67970DEA6C4D5BB320DBD1FA7508E3.description:
Concentration changes in a reaction can be followed indirectly by monitoring
changes in mass, volume and colour.

315D3CE91C57454196D6C93704D1338A.description:
The rate of reaction is expressed as the change in concentration of a particular
reactant/product per unit time.

15C7C489B2C24DC784C1E654324FC155.description:
Species react as a result of collisions of sufficient energy and proper
orientation.

7C81525E360546B9AD9AB2E7B7E1B533.description: Collision theory and rates of reaction

E2CA8E79118D42A3A8EAD4B3FB048AD0.description:
Average bond enthalpy is the energy needed to break one mol of a bond in a
gaseous molecule averaged over similar compounds.

892173A3235743E894120451AD0F2FD1.description: Bond-forming releases energy and bond-breaking requires energy.

5B270BE824CE48A79779C3B4831C54AE.description: The enthalpy change for a reaction that is carried out in a series of steps is equal to the sum of the enthalpy changes for the individual steps.

492CE2C0041047248EB7F8DD45738014.description: ∆H values are usually expressed under standard conditions, given by ∆H°, including standard states.

91D24C92235045CCB581097ABFB33E9A.description: The enthalpy change (∆H) for chemical reactions is indicated in kJ mol-1.

982CB845D5E1465E9833CF98F5ED888C.description: Chemical reactions that involve transfer of heat between the system and the surroundings are described as endothermic or exothermic.

20AB2F3F760F4FC0A7A629A95D6EE900.description: Total energy is conserved in chemical reactions.

670ABEF145E0454C9E0680A3E43AF855.description: Temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of the particles.

6006EA6905E242A4833859594DE3EDE6.description: Heat is a form of energy.

5B129FCCDBDA4261881AA26C1D4C10B5.description: Alloys usually contain more than one metal and have enhanced properties.

612C7FCFF301469280CF150547786E56.description:
The strength of a metallic bond depends on the charge of the ions and the
radius of the metal ion.

82F685269DBF4021A65D5629A6C0557A.description:
A metallic bond is the electrostatic attraction between a lattice of positive ions
and delocalized electrons.

93AFA2BA35B04647B7F1DF9FC295A975.description: The relative strengths of these interactions are London (dispersion) forces < dipole-dipole forces < hydrogen bonds.

FD86FB39645C41C7B3410D4FADB42094.description: Intermolecular forces include London (dispersion) forces, dipole-dipole forces and hydrogen bonding.

E26C1A4911544BFDB0E700158C770F54.description: Carbon and silicon form giant covalent/network covalent structures.

4294A6F0208346A0A8D6C5CFF59441CB.description: Shapes of species are determined by the repulsion of electron pairs according to VSEPR theory.

E022D5501DDF4169AB33BBBFE1840F34.description: Resonance structures occur when there is more than one possible position for a double bond in a molecule.

1B7C77B9EC7B40DEA7AC573785243BC8.description: Some atoms, like Be and B, might form stable compounds with incomplete octets of electrons

FFCAF6C6CA764DA0BC030A09F7BDC842.description: The “octet rule” refers to the tendency of atoms to gain a valence shell with a total of 8 electrons.

36AEE2AD8FB54AFFA5673341287DEC4B.description: Lewis (electron dot) structures show all the valence electrons in a covalently bonded species.

2491008366484123B69BA8034E99FF43.description:
Bond polarity results from the difference in electronegativities of the bonded
atoms.

72C3D80D48C844D984A0D21A3CAF316F.description:
Bond length decreases and bond strength increases as the number of shared
electrons increases.

9A2DA7684A8C4AB69B7F6BEF40869C6A.description:
Single, double and triple covalent bonds involve one, two and three shared
pairs of electrons respectively.

55EF6FAB76A841AA92A260DA5321C6B8.description:
A covalent bond is formed by the electrostatic attraction between a shared pair
of electrons and the positively charged nuclei.

13F6051AB13648458659D44DFC72EDF4.description: Under normal conditions, ionic compounds are usually solids with lattice structures.

CAC305983AF1469C9E3BCD711B04C36C.description: The ionic bond is due to electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions.

B227BDFC501F47E9A285B6ED546BB542.description: The number of electrons lost or gained is determined by the electron configuration of the atom.

21A815FD7B954ED5871F58ADE2C72AC6.description: Negative ions (anions) form by non-metals gaining electrons.

68D1DB53F2C649F0A1DAC7E3FD9071BC.description: Positive ions (cations) form by metals losing valence electrons.

2B26DDC587E44020B385C6766F58802B.description: Oxides change from basic through amphoteric to acidic across a period.

E94C36272F5D4BF0A3D13DD179CD26E3.description: Trends in metallic and non-metallic behaviour are due to the trends above.

E53B52DD5E3840DFA9B17CA47836E583.description:
Vertical and horizontal trends in the periodic table exist for atomic radius, ionic
radius, ionization energy, electron affinity and electronegativity.

758CB1237BA9455ABEFCD6A52DD9E0FC.description: The periodic table shows the positions of metals, non-metals and metalloids.

6FA606B7F9B34518A1CF8A998D9DB1B3.description: The number of the principal energy level and the number of the valence electrons in an atom can be deduced from its position on the periodic table.

99F2CCC2B1C44C9D9F7419F3807309FE.description: The period number (n) is the outer energy level that is occupied by electrons.

A85D991A71714F40962C97C76A515BD0.description: The periodic table consists of groups (vertical columns) and periods (horizontal rows).

D9F3429AA2F74AA99721E518ECFA1F62.description: The periodic table is arranged into four blocks associated with the four sub- levels—s, p, d, and f.

C7A33A04BF1146ACB17388D7F26EEE4B.description: Each orbital has a defined energy state for a given electronic configuration and chemical environment and can hold two electrons of opposite spin.

5CB02A6188324B06A37BAE963852444B.description: Sub-levels contain a fixed number of orbitals, regions of space where there is a high probability of finding an electron.

86D37FE74564461DB93C918848AC7BA3.description: A more detailed model of the atom describes the division of the main energy level into s, p, d and f sub-levels of successively higher energies.

96AC18B1E0FF495880D6943D7AE57033.description: The main energy level or shell is given an integer number, n, and can hold a maximum number of electrons, 2n2.

FBE2C30B231B4EB3889810E17A52B76D.description: The line emission spectrum of hydrogen provides evidence for the existence of electrons in discrete energy levels, which converge at higher energies.

75BEBFCDB1994F4C85611BE89478F73F.description: Emission spectra are produced when photons are emitted from atoms as excited electrons return to a lower energy level.

C430C6361ECF44C8B5E01A09C52A337B.description: The mass spectrometer is used to determine the relative atomic mass of an element from its isotopic composition.

D6717F7A71FF49EDB7E03A8ECFFB2CBC.description: Negatively charged electrons occupy the space outside the nucleus

A8FD2FE8AE2049909C48403654FD1376.description: Atoms contain a positively charged dense nucleus composed of protons and neutrons (nucleons).

F8CAFB10C5074576BCDE215B38456861.description: A standard solution is one of known concentration.

BC641E3E72E24D83833338A87F32392B.description: The molar concentration of a solution is determined by the amount of solute and the volume of solution.

1CD85F0CA56C4EC59340F83A9DC67672.description: The molar volume of an ideal gas is a constant at specified temperature and pressure.

2B7C75CB1432483EA44BC88C24B28BF3.description: Avogadro’s law enables the mole ratio of reacting gases to be determined from volumes of the gases.

44B29FF462E441319E3E61FC500999AA.description: The experimental yield can be different from the theoretical yield.

3AFE717A86914D9A86E1180F336C3E5E.description: Reactants can be either limiting or excess.

94D2BCDAAE0546E1ABC13F8DB865FBDA.description: The empirical formula and molecular formula of a compound give the simplest ratio and the actual number of atoms present in a molecule respectively.

1108D41877BF4A47857C96BD8DF2F017.description: Molar mass (M) has the units g mol-1.

B49F9D5DFAE54A27800F965304DBB3C3.description: Masses of atoms are compared on a scale relative to 12C and are expressed as relative atomic mass (Ar) and relative formula/molecular mass (Mr).

EA6E27FA36B5491AB1304580C192362D.description: The mole is a fixed number of particles and refers to the amount, n, of substance.

E5C0F0B731644CCD8E5C71856B93C35F.description: Mixtures are either homogeneous or heterogeneous.

197D6F018CF94CC5A648587CD9CECC1E.description: Mixtures contain more than one element and/or compound that are not chemically bonded together and so retain their individual properties.

2E25DA729125491D80FC9FD589887625.description: Atoms of different elements combine in fixed ratios to form compounds, which have different properties from their component elements.

D5150D6E3F604E6792DA38AAA819E6DA.description: Introduction to the particulate nature of matter and chemical change
